elements.content: Two Lewis acid–base bifunctional, isostructural metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]­·CH3CN­·2CH3OH (MOF-1) and [Co3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]­·H2O­·2DMF (MOF-2), containing NH2 groups and four-coordinated metal sites were fabricated successfully, and the structures were thoroughly characterized by X-ray crystallography, powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and N2 adsorption/desorption techniques. Satisfactorily, the novel MOFs with a three-dimensional framework were highly efficient and stable heterogeneous catalysts for selective fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates under mild conditions in the absence of solvent. The influences of various reaction parameters on catalytic performance were systematically investigated. Also the catalysts showed excellent versatility to epoxides with different substituents and could be easily recyclable with high activity. Additionally, the self-catalyzed mechanism as well as synergistic mechanism with tetrabutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) for CO2 conversion was proposed.

The influences of various reaction parameters on catalytic performance were systematically investigated. Also the catalysts showed excellent versatility to epoxides with different substituents and could be easily recyclable with high activity. Additionally, the self-catalyzed mechanism as well as synergistic mechanism with tetrabutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) for CO2 conversion was proposed.

elements.content: As is well-known, CO2 plays a large part in the greenhouse gases, and the aggravating greenhouse effect has caused great threat to human life. Therefore, the reduction of the greenhouse gas emissions that promote climate change is globally urgent. In addition, CO2 is an abundant, nontoxic, and biorenewable C1 resource, and taking advantage of CO2 as an environmental friendly raw material for the production of commercially valuable compounds has attractive prospects. One of the most promising studies in this field is the 100% atom-economical coupling of CO2 and epoxides for cyclic carbonates synthesis (), as the products have numerous potential applications ranging from lithium-ion battery electrolytes to intermediates of fine chemicals.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As is well-known, CO2 plays a large part in the greenhouse gases, and the aggravating greenhouse effect has caused great threat to human life. Therefore, the reduction of the greenhouse gas emissions that promote climate change is globally urgent. In addition, CO2 is an abundant, nontoxic, and biorenewable C1 resource, and taking advantage of CO2 as an environmental friendly raw material for the production of commercially valuable compounds has attractive prospects. One of the most promising studies in this field is the 100% atom-economical coupling of CO2 and epoxides for cyclic carbonates synthesis (), as the products have numerous potential applications ranging from lithium-ion battery electrolytes to intermediates of fine chemicals.

elements.clean_text: 1  Coupling of CO2 and Epoxides to Cyclic Carbonates

elements.content: Up to now, various catalytic systems have been developed for the CO2 fixation to cyclic carbonates, including homogeneous and heterogeneous ones, such as ionic liquids (ILs), metal complexes, porous organic polymers (POPs), graphite oxide, and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). While homogeneous catalysts possess excellent catalytic performance under mild conditions, the problems of product separation and catalyst recyclability still seriously restrict industrial applications. On the contrary, heterogeneous catalysts commendably solve the problems of product separation and catalyst reutilization, especially for the novel porous materialsMOFs, which have extensive applications in catalysis due to their well-ordered tunable porous structures, adjustable compositions, and exceptional textural properties. Furthermore, MOFs feature high CO2 adsorption capacity and thus enhance the possibility of epoxide–CO2 interaction by multifold times. Thus, a series of MOFs such as ZIF-68, ZIF-90, Mg-MOF-74, IRMOF-3, UIO-66-NH2, MIL-68­(In)­NH2, and Gea-MOF-1 have been developed for the catalytic conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. In order to obtain satisfactory activity and selectivity, harsh reaction conditions such as high temperature and CO2 pressure are needed, and some organic solvents are necessary, which are harmful to human beings and the environment. Moreover, from pioneering theoretical and experimental results, it is well recognized that Lewis acid–base or Lewis acid–nucleophiles are indispensable in the catalyst system for the CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides, where Lewis acid activates epoxide by the formation of an adduct, and Lewis base activates CO2 or nucleophile favors the ring-opening of epoxide. Inspired by the above reaction principle, we pursued to design novel MOFs with both Lewis acid and base species in the framework, which is anticipated to be endowed with satisfactory activity for the coupling reaction.
elements.clean_text: Up to now, various catalytic systems have been developed for the CO2 fixation to cyclic carbonates, including homogeneous and heterogeneous ones, such as ionic liquids (ILs), metal complexes, porous organic polymers (POPs), graphite oxide, and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). While homogeneous catalysts possess excellent catalytic performance under mild conditions, the problems of product separation and catalyst recyclability still seriously restrict industrial applications. On the contrary, heterogeneous catalysts commendably solve the problems of product separation and catalyst reutilization, especially for the novel porous materialsMOFs, which have extensive applications in catalysis due to their well-ordered tunable porous structures, adjustable compositions, and exceptional textural properties. Furthermore, MOFs feature high CO2 adsorption capacity and thus enhance the possibility of epoxide-CO2 interaction by multifold times. Thus, a series of MOFs such as ZIF-68, ZIF-90, Mg-MOF-74, IRMOF-3, UIO-66-NH2, MIL-68(In)NH2, and Gea-MOF-1 have been developed for the catalytic conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. In order to obtain satisfactory activity and selectivity, harsh reaction conditions such as high temperature and CO2 pressure are needed, and some organic solvents are necessary, which are harmful to human beings and the environment. Moreover, from pioneering theoretical and experimental results, it is well recognized that Lewis acid-base or Lewis acid-nucleophiles are indispensable in the catalyst system for the CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides, where Lewis acid activates epoxide by the formation of an adduct, and Lewis base activates CO2 or nucleophile favors the ring-opening of epoxide. Inspired by the above reaction principle, we pursued to design novel MOFs with both Lewis acid and base species in the framework, which is anticipated to be endowed with satisfactory activity for the coupling reaction.

elements.content: Herein, two novel MOFs ([Zn3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]­·CH3CN­·2CH3OH and [Co3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]­·H2O­·2DMF) possessing free amino groups and four-coordinated metal sites were developed for the first time. And the catalytic performance of the obtained MOFs was investigated toward the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. For the catalytic process, the free amino and metal Zn/or Co sites served as a Lewis base and Lewis acid to respectively activate CO2 and epoxide, and the obtained MOFs catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic performance for cyclic carbonates synthesis in the absence of solvent and mild conditions. The reported catalysts also exhibited excellent recycle performance even after six reuses and no obvious decrease of catalytic activity. Additionally, the self-catalyzed mechanism of MOFs as well as synergistic mechanism with Bu4NBr for CO2 conversion was proposed.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis was recorded on an Agilent Technology SuperNova Eos Dual system with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) microfocus source and focusing multilayer mirror optics at 293 K and processed using CrysAlisPro. The structures were solved and refined using full-matrix least-squares based on F2 with the programs SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97. The patterns of powder X-ray diffraction were conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) for phase identification. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis was performed on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a NETZSCH STA 449F3 thermal analyzer from 30 to 450 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min in a flowing 150 mL/min N2 atmosphere. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C by using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 system. The samples were degassed under a vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h before measurement. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis was recorded by using a PerkinElmer OES Optima 8300 instrument. Gas chromotography analysis was performed on Agilent GC-7890A equipped with a capillary column (Agilent 19091J-413) using flame ionization detector.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information

All reagents and solvents were commercially available. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis was recorded on an Agilent Technology SuperNova Eos Dual system with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) microfocus source and focusing multilayer mirror optics at 293 K and processed using CrysAlisPro. The structures were solved and refined using full-matrix least-squares based on F2 with the programs SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97. The patterns of powder X-ray diffraction were conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) for phase identification. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis was performed on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a NETZSCH STA 449F3 thermal analyzer from 30 to 450 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min in a flowing 150 mL/min N2 atmosphere. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at -196 °C by using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 system. The samples were degassed under a vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h before measurement. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis was recorded by using a PerkinElmer OES Optima 8300 instrument. Gas chromotography analysis was performed on Agilent GC-7890A equipped with a capillary column (Agilent 19091J-413) using flame ionization detector.

elements.content: MOF-1 was prepared by a solvothermal method in a typical run. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.5 mmol, and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (CH3OH/CH3CN/H2O = 1:2:2­(v/v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 60 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to 100 °C. The resulting mixture was kept static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by ethanol and dried in air for 24 h.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MOF Catalysts

Synthesis of [Zn3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]⋅CH3CN⋅2CH3OH (MOF-1)

MOF-1 was prepared by a solvothermal method in a typical run. Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.5 mmol, and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (CH3OH/CH3CN/H2O = 1:2:2(v/v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 60 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to 100 °C. The resulting mixture was kept static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by ethanol and dried in air for 24 h.

elements.content: MOF-2 was prepared by solvothermal method similarly, in a typical synthetic run, Co­(NO3)2·6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.0 mmol and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (DMF/H2O = 4:1­(v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 72 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to 100 °C and keeping static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by DMF and H2O then dried in air for 24 h.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]⋅H2O⋅2DMF (MOF-2)

MOF-2 was prepared by solvothermal method similarly, in a typical synthetic run, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.0 mmol and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (DMF/H2O = 4:1(v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 72 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to 100 °C and keeping static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by DMF and H2O then dried in air for 24 h.

elements.content: All the cycloaddition reactions were performed in a 50 mL stainless-steel autoclave with a magnetic stirring. Typically, air in the autoclave was first purged with CO2, then MOF catalyst 100 mg, cocatalyst tertbutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) 100 mg and propylene oxide (PO) 2.0 g (34.5 mmol) were added, and then the autoclave was heated to the target temperature followed by introducing CO2 to a preset pressure and maintaining stirring for a fixed time. Upon completion, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature using an ice–water bath and depressurized slowly; the reaction mixtures were diluted with ethyl acetate, and the catalysts could be separated by centrifugation. The products were quantitatively analyzed by GC, and the MOF catalyst was washed with ethyl acetate, then dried under a vacuum and reused for next run.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Activity Test

All the cycloaddition reactions were performed in a 50 mL stainless-steel autoclave with a magnetic stirring. Typically, air in the autoclave was first purged with CO2, then MOF catalyst 100 mg, cocatalyst tertbutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) 100 mg and propylene oxide (PO) 2.0 g (34.5 mmol) were added, and then the autoclave was heated to the target temperature followed by introducing CO2 to a preset pressure and maintaining stirring for a fixed time. Upon completion, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature using an ice-water bath and depressurized slowly; the reaction mixtures were diluted with ethyl acetate, and the catalysts could be separated by centrifugation. The products were quantitatively analyzed by GC, and the MOF catalyst was washed with ethyl acetate, then dried under a vacuum and reused for next run.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveal that MOF-1 and MOF-2 are isostructural, which crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group and display a 3D framework with 1D tunnels. As a representative, the MOF-1 structure is shown in ; the asymmetric unit of MOF-1 consists of one and a half crystallographically unique Zn­(II) ions, one deprotonated Hbtc2– anion, and one atz– ligand. The central Zn1 atom is located in a distorted tetrahedron geometry and coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of N1 and N2i from two different atz– anions and two oxygen atoms of O6 and O4ii from two different Hbtc2– anions (symmetry codes: (i) 1 – x, 1 – y, 2 – z; (ii) x, 1 – y, 1/2 + z). In the tetrahedron, the distances of Zn–N [1.996(3)–2.010(3) Å] and Zn–O [1.919(3)–1.942(3) Å] are basically comparable with those observed in reported Zn­(II) complexes, and bond angle around the central Zn1 ion varies from 98.73(12)° to 119.35(11)°. Zn2 atom is located on special positions (1.00 0.80121 0.75) with the site occupancy factor being 0.5 and displays a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, in which O2 and N3iv atoms occupy the vertex position and three atoms (O1, O2iii, O1v) and one N atom (N3vi) defines the equatorial plane [symmetry codes: (iii) 2 – x, y, 3/2 – z (iv) 1/2 + x, 1/2 + y, z (v) 2 – x, y, 3/2 – z (vi) 3/2 – x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 – z)]. The Zn2–O2 bond [2.678(5) Å] is longer than the Zn2–O1, Zn1–O4, and Zn1–O6 bonds [1.967(3), 1.942(3), and 1.919(3) Å]. The apexes bond angle O2–Zn2–N3iv is 153.28(8)°, and the bond angles around Zn2 atom vary from 52.55(9) to 116.65(6)°. The H3btc ligand in MOF-1 loses two protons to form the Hbtc2– anion and adopts one bridging coordination mode, in which the carboxylate groups adopting η1: η1:μ1 and η1:η0:μ1 (as shown in Supporting Information, Figure S1). The atz– anion is a three linker and utilizes 1,2,4-position N atoms to bridge three Zn centers, while the amino groups remain free and connected with two adjacent ones to form a 1D beautiful sinusoidal ruffling chain along the c axis (Figure S2). The amplitude of the sinusoidal chain is about 4.17 Å, whereas the period is about 15.62 Å. Each chain is connected with four neighboring ones through Hbtc2– ligands and generates a 3D framework. This arrangement leads to a rectangular open-ended, hollow single-wall nanotube with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 13.5 × 13.5 Å. As calculated by PLATON, MOF-1 possesses large solvent-accessible volumes with 60.02% of the unit cell volume. From the topological point of view, each Zn2 atom is connected by two atz– anions and two Hbtc2– ligands, which can be simplified as a four-connected node; each Hbtc2– ligand is simplified by a three-way tube linker linking three Zn­(II) centers. However, two adjacent Zn1 centers connected by two azt– anions can be simplified as a four-connected node. Accordingly, the whole network can be extended to a 3D 3,4,6-connected framework with the Schläfli symbol {4.62}2{4.64.8}­{46.64.85}, which is recognized for the first time (). Similarly, the Co1 and Co2 atoms in MOF-2 both present the identical ligand models with Zn1 atom as shown in Supporting Information (Figure S3 and Figure S4). Further details of the X-ray diffraction structural analyses of MOF-1 and MOF-2 are given in Table S1 and Table S3, and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S2 and Table S4. The BET surface areas were measured at 175 m2·g–1 and 179m2·g–1, and the pore volumes were 0.21 m3·g–1 and 0.11 m3·g–1, respectively, for MOF-1 and MOF-2. Using the BJH model, mesopores width of 4.8 and 4.4 nm were available in MOF-1 and MOF-2, which would provide spacious accessibility for the reactants and products to diffuse and interact with more catalytic sites.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

MOF Catalyst Characterizations

X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveal that MOF-1 and MOF-2 are isostructural, which crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group and display a 3D framework with 1D tunnels. As a representative, the MOF-1 structure is shown in ; the asymmetric unit of MOF-1 consists of one and a half crystallographically unique Zn(II) ions, one deprotonated Hbtc2- anion, and one atz- ligand. The central Zn1 atom is located in a distorted tetrahedron geometry and coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of N1 and N2i from two different atz- anions and two oxygen atoms of O6 and O4ii from two different Hbtc2- anions (symmetry codes: (i) 1 - x, 1 - y, 2 - z; (ii) x, 1 - y, 1/2 + z). In the tetrahedron, the distances of Zn-N [1.996(3)-2.010(3) Å] and Zn-O [1.919(3)-1.942(3) Å] are basically comparable with those observed in reported Zn(II) complexes, and bond angle around the central Zn1 ion varies from 98.73(12)° to 119.35(11)°. Zn2 atom is located on special positions (1.00 0.80121 0.75) with the site occupancy factor being 0.5 and displays a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, in which O2 and N3iv atoms occupy the vertex position and three atoms (O1, O2iii, O1v) and one N atom (N3vi) defines the equatorial plane [symmetry codes: (iii) 2 - x, y, 3/2 - z (iv) 1/2 + x, 1/2 + y, z (v) 2 - x, y, 3/2 - z (vi) 3/2 - x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 - z)]. The Zn2-O2 bond [2.678(5) Å] is longer than the Zn2-O1, Zn1-O4, and Zn1-O6 bonds [1.967(3), 1.942(3), and 1.919(3) Å]. The apexes bond angle O2-Zn2-N3iv is 153.28(8)°, and the bond angles around Zn2 atom vary from 52.55(9) to 116.65(6)°. The H3btc ligand in MOF-1 loses two protons to form the Hbtc2- anion and adopts one bridging coordination mode, in which the carboxylate groups adopting η1: η1:μ1 and η1:η0:μ1 (as shown in Supporting Information, Figure S1). The atz- anion is a three linker and utilizes 1,2,4-position N atoms to bridge three Zn centers, while the amino groups remain free and connected with two adjacent ones to form a 1D beautiful sinusoidal ruffling chain along the c axis (Figure S2). The amplitude of the sinusoidal chain is about 4.17 Å, whereas the period is about 15.62 Å. Each chain is connected with four neighboring ones through Hbtc2- ligands and generates a 3D framework. This arrangement leads to a rectangular open-ended, hollow single-wall nanotube with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 13.5 × 13.5 Å. As calculated by PLATON, MOF-1 possesses large solvent-accessible volumes with 60.02% of the unit cell volume. From the topological point of view, each Zn2 atom is connected by two atz- anions and two Hbtc2- ligands, which can be simplified as a four-connected node; each Hbtc2- ligand is simplified by a three-way tube linker linking three Zn(II) centers. However, two adjacent Zn1 centers connected by two azt- anions can be simplified as a four-connected node. Accordingly, the whole network can be extended to a 3D 3,4,6-connected framework with the Schläfli symbol {4.62}2{4.64.8}{46.64.85}, which is recognized for the first time (). Similarly, the Co1 and Co2 atoms in MOF-2 both present the identical ligand models with Zn1 atom as shown in Supporting Information (Figure S3 and Figure S4). Further details of the X-ray diffraction structural analyses of MOF-1 and MOF-2 are given in Table S1 and Table S3, and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S2 and Table S4. The BET surface areas were measured at 175 m2⋅g-1 and 179m2⋅g-1, and the pore volumes were 0.21 m3⋅g-1 and 0.11 m3⋅g-1, respectively, for MOF-1 and MOF-2. Using the BJH model, mesopores width of 4.8 and 4.4 nm were available in MOF-1 and MOF-2, which would provide spacious accessibility for the reactants and products to diffuse and interact with more catalytic sites.

elements.content: The XRD reflections of MOF-1 and MOF-2 are matched perfectly with the simulated single crystal pattern (A and Figure S5), which confirm the structural integrity and phase homogeneity. B shows the FT-IR spectrum of MOF-1. The peak observed at 3335 cm–1 was the characteristic peak of primary amine. A broad band at around 3162 cm–1 was attributed to the O–H stretching vibration, and the stretching vibrations of −OH and −NH2 caused red shifts due to the existence of intramolecular hydrogen bondings. The absorption band appeared at 1627 cm–1 was attributed to the CO stretching vibration. The peak around 1576 cm–1 to 1439 cm–1 belonged to the stretching vibration of CC of the benzene ring. The peak at 1060 cm–1 was the stretching vibration of C–O. The absorption bands at 765 and 721 cm–1 corresponded to the N–H flexural vibrations of primary amine. The peak at 500 cm–1 was connected with the Zn–O bonds stretching vibration in MOF-1. The FT-IR spectrum of MOF-2 was identical with that of MOF-1 (Figure S6). All the FT-IR characteristic peaks combined with the XRD reflections demonstrated the successful synthesis of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
XRD and FT-IR

The XRD reflections of MOF-1 and MOF-2 are matched perfectly with the simulated single crystal pattern (A and Figure S5), which confirm the structural integrity and phase homogeneity. B shows the FT-IR spectrum of MOF-1. The peak observed at 3335 cm-1 was the characteristic peak of primary amine. A broad band at around 3162 cm-1 was attributed to the O-H stretching vibration, and the stretching vibrations of -OH and -NH2 caused red shifts due to the existence of intramolecular hydrogen bondings. The absorption band appeared at 1627 cm-1 was attributed to the CO stretching vibration. The peak around 1576 cm-1 to 1439 cm-1 belonged to the stretching vibration of CC of the benzene ring. The peak at 1060 cm-1 was the stretching vibration of C-O. The absorption bands at 765 and 721 cm-1 corresponded to the N-H flexural vibrations of primary amine. The peak at 500 cm-1 was connected with the Zn-O bonds stretching vibration in MOF-1. The FT-IR spectrum of MOF-2 was identical with that of MOF-1 (Figure S6). All the FT-IR characteristic peaks combined with the XRD reflections demonstrated the successful synthesis of MOFs.

elements.content: TGA was performed to test the thermal stability and the nature of the framework construction of MOFs. A shows the TGA curve of as-synthesized MOF-1. The preliminary 0.3% weight loss before 150 °C was speculated to the loss of absorbed water. The tardy weight loss of 11.5% within 150–360 °C corresponded to the removal of one CH3CN and two CH3OH per formula unit (cal. 11.9%). The dramatic weight loss observed within 360–430 °C indicated that the framework of MOF-1 collapsed. The TGA curve of as-synthesized MOF-2 is shown in B. The weight loss of 1.9% before 100 °C belonged to the removal of one H2O per formula unit (cal. 2.0%), and the weight loss of 15.4% within 100–200 °C corresponded to the removal of two DMF per formula unit (cal. 15.8%). Therefore, the catalysts exhibited excellent thermostability as the catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 was performed at 90 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

TGA was performed to test the thermal stability and the nature of the framework construction of MOFs. A shows the TGA curve of as-synthesized MOF-1. The preliminary 0.3% weight loss before 150 °C was speculated to the loss of absorbed water. The tardy weight loss of 11.5% within 150-360 °C corresponded to the removal of one CH3CN and two CH3OH per formula unit (cal. 11.9%). The dramatic weight loss observed within 360-430 °C indicated that the framework of MOF-1 collapsed. The TGA curve of as-synthesized MOF-2 is shown in B. The weight loss of 1.9% before 100 °C belonged to the removal of one H2O per formula unit (cal. 2.0%), and the weight loss of 15.4% within 100-200 °C corresponded to the removal of two DMF per formula unit (cal. 15.8%). Therefore, the catalysts exhibited excellent thermostability as the catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 was performed at 90 °C.

elements.content: The catalytic activity of as-synthesized MOF-1 and MOF-2 were tested toward the model cycloaddition of CO2 to PO (). It has been reported that metal atom in MOF can coordinate with the oxygen of epoxide to form an M–O adduct to promote the ring-opening reaction. According to the crystal structural analysis, there were free amine groups, which could serve as Lewis base to activate CO2. And with cooperative effects of Lewis acid–base coming from MOF catalysts, 85% and 57% PC yields with 98% selectivity could be obtained at 140 °C and 1.0 MPa pressure CO2 for 12 h over MOF-1 and MOF-2 independently without any cocatalyst and solvent participation (entries 1–2). To further improve the catalytic activity, different cocatalysts were chosen to cooperate with MOF-1 for the coupling reaction under milder temperature of 90 °C (entries 3–7). It was found that both MOFs and Bu4NBr gave the low activities when used alone (entry 11–13). The cocatalyst had great influence on this catalytic conversion. With cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as the cocatalyst, PC yield reached 87%, while only a little PO was converted to PC with respective KI, KBr, or NaCl cocatalyst. Noticeably, MOF-1 combined with Bu4NBr showed significant activity, and 92% PC yield with 99% selectivity was obtained under the conditions of 90 °C, 1.0 MPa for 6 h; the enhanced activity was attributed to the anion nucleophilicity from the Bu4NBr cocatalyst favoring the ring-opening of epoxide. So all of the following investigations were carried out with Bu4NBr as cocatalyst. When MOF-1 was replaced by MOF-2, 72% PC yield with 99% selectivity was obtained at the same reaction conditions (entry 10). Even a moderate catalytic activity of MOF-1 was exhibited at much lower temperature of 50 °C (entry 9). Although MOF-2 possessed crystal structure similar to MOF-1, the decrease of catalytic activity of MOF-2 was possibly attributed to the weaker Lewis acidity of Co2+ center than Zn2+. Zn2+ was more superior to Co2+ for inducing the opening of the epoxy-ring, which was regarded as the rate-determining step of cyclic carbonate synthesis, so MOF-1 was chosen for further investigation.

Screening of Cocatalyst

And with cooperative effects of Lewis acid-base coming from MOF catalysts, 85% and 57% PC yields with 98% selectivity could be obtained at 140 °C and 1.0 MPa pressure CO2 for 12 h over MOF-1 and MOF-2 independently without any cocatalyst and solvent participation (entries 1-2). To further improve the catalytic activity, different cocatalysts were chosen to cooperate with MOF-1 for the coupling reaction under milder temperature of 90 °C (entries 3-7). It was found that both MOFs and Bu4NBr gave the low activities when used alone (entry 11-13). The cocatalyst had great influence on this catalytic conversion. With cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as the cocatalyst, PC yield reached 87%, while only a little PO was converted to PC with respective KI, KBr, or NaCl cocatalyst. Noticeably, MOF-1 combined with Bu4NBr showed significant activity, and 92% PC yield with 99% selectivity was obtained under the conditions of 90 °C, 1.0 MPa for 6 h; the enhanced activity was attributed to the anion nucleophilicity from the Bu4NBr cocatalyst favoring the ring-opening of epoxide. So all of the following investigations were carried out with Bu4NBr as cocatalyst. When MOF-1 was replaced by MOF-2, 72% PC yield with 99% selectivity was obtained at the same reaction conditions (entry 10). Even a moderate catalytic activity of MOF-1 was exhibited at much lower temperature of 50 °C (entry 9). Although MOF-2 possessed crystal structure similar to MOF-1, the decrease of catalytic activity of MOF-2 was possibly attributed to the weaker Lewis acidity of Co2+ center than Zn2+. Reaction conditions: PO 34.5 mmol, MOF 100 mg, cocatalyst 100 mg, 1.0 MPa.

Based on GC analysis.

Further investigations toward PC synthesis over the MOF-1 catalyst was conducted at different catalyst loadings, temperature, CO2 pressure, and time to optimize these reaction variables. As shown in A, the PC yield enhanced with increasing amount of MOF-1 catalyst. When the amount of MOF-1 was increased to 100 mg, the PC yield could reach above 90%. From the viewpoint of economy, the following reactions were performed using 100 mg of catalyst. B shows the influence of reaction temperature on catalytic performance. With an increase of the reaction temperature, a higher PC yield was obtained in the range of 60–100 °C, and the selectivities to PC were excellent. This phenomenon was due to the more effective collisions between the active species and substrate molecules at the elevated temperature. The influence of CO2 pressure on catalytic activity was illustrated in C. When the pressure was raised from 0.5 to 1.0 MPa at 90 °C, it had a dramatic enhancement on the PC yield. And the PC yield had a moderate increase with increasing CO2 pressure in the region of 1.0–2.5 MPa, which was ascribed to the fact that the dissolution of CO2 as a reactant should be a positive impact at low CO2 pressure. On the basis of the above discussion, 1.0 MPa CO2 pressure was selectable for conversion of CO2 to PC. The dependence of reaction time on PC yield was finally examined under the above optimized conditions (D). The PC yield increased markedly within the first 4 h; when further prolonging the reaction time for more than 4 h the PC yield increased smoothly. After the reaction proceeded for 7 h, PO was almost quantitatively converted to the PC product with the perfect selectivity to PC.

elements.content: The above-mentioned results involving the conversion of CO2 to PC can be satisfactorily achieved with the coexistence of zinc-amino species based MOF-1 and Bu4NBr under mild temperature and CO2 pressure (90 °C, 1.0 MPa). As shown in , comparisons were made between the present MOF-1/Bu4NBr and various MOF catalysts reported in the literature for the cyclic carbonate synthesis. The super activity of MOF-1/Bu4NBr under mild and solvent-free conditions is of the utmost importance for practical conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates.

SO, styrene oxide.

AGE, allyl glycidyl ether.

PO, propylene oxide.

As a heterogeneous catalyst, the recyclability is of vital importance in practical applications. As shown in A, after six recycles of MOF-1, the PC yield did not obviously decreased, and the selectivity was still above 99%, suggesting the MOF-1 possessed good recyclability. From the FT-IR spectra analysis of the synthesized and reused MOF-1 (B), there appeared two new absorption peaks at 2344 and 1792 cm–1, respectively, attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of physical adsorbed CO2 and the stretching vibration of CO in propylene carbonate which was slightly adsorbed in the pores of spent MOF-1. Moreover, TGA curves of MOF-1 before and after six reuses were illustrated in C. With the temperature increase from 150 to 230 °C, the decomposition rate appeared a tiny increase for the spent MOF-1, which was possibly due to the concomitant removal of PC product, and the TGA result was consistent with the FT-IR analysis. Moreover, the solution after reaction and removal of the catalysts was tested by ICP analysis, and proved that no Zn component leached from MOF-1 catalyst in the solution. Hence, the slight decrease of catalytic activity after six recycles was due to the residual PC product, which partially covered the active sites of the catalyst.

Recycle Performance of MOF-1 Catalyst

As a heterogeneous catalyst, the recyclability is of vital importance in practical applications. As shown in A, after six recycles of MOF-1, the PC yield did not obviously decreased, and the selectivity was still above 99%, suggesting the MOF-1 possessed good recyclability. From the FT-IR spectra analysis of the synthesized and reused MOF-1 (B), there appeared two new absorption peaks at 2344 and 1792 cm-1, respectively, attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of physical adsorbed CO2  and the stretching vibration of CO in propylene carbonate which was slightly adsorbed in the pores of spent MOF-1. Moreover, TGA curves of MOF-1 before and after six reuses were illustrated in C. With the temperature increase from 150 to 230 °C, the decomposition rate appeared a tiny increase for the spent MOF-1, which was possibly due to the concomitant removal of PC product, and the TGA result was consistent with the FT-IR analysis. Moreover, the solution after reaction and removal of the catalysts was tested by ICP analysis, and proved that no Zn component leached from MOF-1 catalyst in the solution. Hence, the slight decrease of catalytic activity after six recycles was due to the residual PC product, which partially covered the active sites of the catalyst.

elements.content: The cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides that with various substituents were studied to verify the potential generality of MOF-1 catalyst, as shown in . The MOF-1 catalyst revealed efficient catalytic performance toward the conversion of CO2 with various epoxides in high yields and selectivities (entries 1–5). Among all of the epoxides investigated, epichlorohydrin was the most active (entry 3) as the electron-withdrawing nature of chloromethyl group favored the ring-opening of epichlorohydrin. It was regarded that the rate-determining step of the cycloaddition reaction mainly focuses on the ring-opening of epoxide. When the steric hindrance deriving from side chain substituent of epoxides increased, the catalytic activity was restricted. In the case of styrene oxide and cyclohexene oxide, high product yields were obtained by increasing the reaction temperature and prolonging the reaction time (entries 4 and 5). Hence, the MOF catalyst possesses great versatility to various epoxides.
elements.clean_text:
Cycloaddition of CO2 with Various Epoxides

The cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides that with various substituents were studied to verify the potential generality of MOF-1 catalyst, as shown in . The MOF-1 catalyst revealed efficient catalytic performance toward the conversion of CO2 with various epoxides in high yields and selectivities (entries 1-5). Among all of the epoxides investigated, epichlorohydrin was the most active (entry 3) as the electron-withdrawing nature of chloromethyl group favored the ring-opening of epichlorohydrin. It was regarded that the rate-determining step of the cycloaddition reaction mainly focuses on the ring-opening of epoxide. When the steric hindrance deriving from side chain substituent of epoxides increased, the catalytic activity was restricted. In the case of styrene oxide and cyclohexene oxide, high product yields were obtained by increasing the reaction temperature and prolonging the reaction time (entries 4 and 5). Hence, the MOF catalyst possesses great versatility to various epoxides.

Based on GC analysis.

Previous reports have suggested that Lewis acid and Lewis base are both necessary for conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. According to X-ray crystallography as well as other characteristic techniques, Lewis acid and Lewis base coexisted in MOF-1 catalyst, and the FT-IR of MOF-1 after adsorbed CO2 showed two new bands at 1787 and 2330 cm–1 (), which correspond to the new asymmetric CO vibration of carbamate salt I (shown in ) and the asymmetric stretching vibration of physical adsorbed CO2. The formed carbamate salt suggested that CO2 was successfully activated by the Lewis base site in MOF-1. On the basis of these observations, a feasible mechanism over independent MOF-1 catalyst was illustrated in . Initially, the Lewis acid Zn site bonded the oxygen atom of epoxide to polarize the C–O bond and assisted in the opening the epoxy ring more easily. The carbamate salt I was formed by activation of CO2 and then acted as a nucleophile to attack the β-carbon atom with the less sterically hindered epoxide leading to the opening of the epoxy ring, and the activated CO2 was simultaneously inserted in the opened epoxide. Finally, the ring-closure took place to obtain the desirable product along with the catalyst regeneration. As the steric hindrance of the carbamate salt, the epoxy-ring opening and the insertion of CO2 became much tougher, and thus harsh reaction conditions of high temperature and long time were required for the satisfactory product yield.

Proposed Reaction Mechanism

Previous reports have suggested that Lewis acid and Lewis base are both necessary for conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates. According to X-ray crystallography as well as other characteristic techniques, Lewis acid and Lewis base coexisted in MOF-1 catalyst, and the FT-IR of MOF-1 after adsorbed CO2 showed two new bands at 1787 and 2330 cm-1 (), which correspond to the new asymmetric CO vibration of carbamate salt I (shown in ) and the asymmetric stretching vibration of physical adsorbed CO2. The formed carbamate salt suggested that CO2 was successfully activated by the Lewis base site in MOF-1. On the basis of these observations, a feasible mechanism over independent MOF-1 catalyst was illustrated in . Initially, the Lewis acid Zn site bonded the oxygen atom of epoxide to polarize the C-O bond and assisted in the opening the epoxy ring more easily. The carbamate salt I was formed by activation of CO2 and then acted as a nucleophile to attack the β-carbon atom with the less sterically hindered epoxide leading to the opening of the epoxy ring, and the activated CO2 was simultaneously inserted in the opened epoxide. Finally, the ring-closure took place to obtain the desirable product along with the catalyst regeneration. As the steric hindrance of the carbamate salt, the epoxy-ring opening and the insertion of CO2 became much tougher, and thus harsh reaction conditions of high temperature and long time were required for the satisfactory product yield.

elements.content: Additionally, the synergistic catalysis mechanism in the presence of Bu4NBr was illustrated in . Epoxide was first activated by the Lewis acid Zn site, and subsequently Br– of Bu4NBr as a strong nucleophile attacked β-carbon atom with the less sterically hindered of epoxide to help the epoxy-ring opening. The synergistic effects of Zn and Bu4NBr resulted in the epoxide ring-opening facilely, and similarly the activated CO2 species attacked the ring-opened epoxide to form an intermediate (III). Finally, the ring-closure took place to generate cyclic carbonate along with the catalysts regeneration, which moved to the next cycle. In the synergistic catalysis of MOF-1/Bu4NBr, the nucleophilic anion of Bu4NBr cocatalyst helped opening of the epoxy-ring and thus favored the subsequent CO2 cycloaddition to the opened epoxide. Moreover, the experimental data in (entries 1 and 3) also indicated that the catalytic activity over MOF-1/Bu4NBr was much faster than that over MOF-1 catalyst alone. Thus, the cycloaddition reaction could proceed under milder reaction conditions of 90 °C, 1.0 MPa over MOF-1/Bu4NBr catalysts.

elements.content: In conclusion, the novel MOFs with Lewis acid–base bifunctionalities were successfully developed and structurally characterized. The catalyst exhibited an outstanding catalytic activity for the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates and especially cooperated with Bu4NBr cocatalyst. Excellent product yields of 92% and 99% selectivity to propylene carbonate were achieved at 90 °C and 1 MPa CO2 for 6 h in the absence of additional organic solvent. The heterogeneous MOF catalyst also showed the universality and good recyclability with no obvious loss of catalytic activity even after six reuses. Compared with the reported heterogeneous MOFs, the present catalytic process is mild and environmentally benign.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, the novel MOFs with Lewis acid-base bifunctionalities were successfully developed and structurally characterized. The catalyst exhibited an outstanding catalytic activity for the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates and especially cooperated with Bu4NBr cocatalyst. Excellent product yields of 92% and 99% selectivity to propylene carbonate were achieved at 90 °C and 1 MPa CO2 for 6 h in the absence of additional organic solvent. The heterogeneous MOF catalyst also showed the universality and good recyclability with no obvious loss of catalytic activity even after six reuses. Compared with the reported heterogeneous MOFs, the present catalytic process is mild and environmentally benign.

cln_elements.content:
MOF-1 was prepared by a solvothermal method in a typical run. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.5 mmol, and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (CH3OH/CH3CN/H2O = 1:2:2­(v/v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 60 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to 100 °C. The resulting mixture was kept static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by ethanol and dried in air for 24 h.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>3</sub>(Hbtc)<sub>2</sub>(atz)<sub>2</sub>]­·H<sub>2</sub>O­·2DMF (MOF-<bold>2</bold>)

MOF-2 was prepared by solvothermal method similarly, in a typical synthetic run, Co­(NO3)2·6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.0 mmol and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (DMF/H2O = 4:1­(v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 72 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to 100 °C and keeping static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C·h–1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by DMF and H2O then dried in air for 24 h.

Preparation of MOF Catalysts

Synthesis of [Zn3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]⋅CH3CN⋅2CH3OH (MOF-1)

MOF-1 was prepared by a solvothermal method in a typical run. Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.5 mmol, and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (CH3OH/CH3CN/H2O = 1:2:2(v/v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 60 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to 100 °C. The resulting mixture was kept static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by ethanol and dried in air for 24 h.

Synthesis of [Co3(Hbtc)2(atz)2]⋅H2O⋅2DMF (MOF-2)

MOF-2 was prepared by solvothermal method similarly, in a typical synthetic run, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O 1.0 mmol, trimesic acid (H3btc) 1.0 mmol and 3-amino 1,2,4-triazole (Hatz) 1.0 mmol were dissolved in 10 mL of mixed solvents (DMF/H2O = 4:1(v/v)) followed by charging into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heating to 150 °C for 72 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to 100 °C and keeping static at 100 °C for 8 h, then with a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1 cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed by DMF and H2O then dried in air for 24 h.

cln_elements.content:
Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveal that MOF-1 and MOF-2 are isostructural, which crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group and display a 3D framework with 1D tunnels. As a representative, the MOF-1 structure is shown in ; the asymmetric unit of MOF-1 consists of one and a half crystallographically unique Zn­(II) ions, one deprotonated Hbtc2– anion, and one atz– ligand. The central Zn1 atom is located in a distorted tetrahedron geometry and coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of N1 and N2i from two different atz– anions and two oxygen atoms of O6 and O4ii from two different Hbtc2– anions (symmetry codes: (i) 1 – x, 1 – y, 2 – z; (ii) x, 1 – y, 1/2 + z). In the tetrahedron, the distances of Zn–N [1.996(3)–2.010(3) Å] and Zn–O [1.919(3)–1.942(3) Å] are basically comparable with those observed in reported Zn­(II) complexes, and bond angle around the central Zn1 ion varies from 98.73(12)° to 119.35(11)°. Zn2 atom is located on special positions (1.00 0.80121 0.75) with the site occupancy factor being 0.5 and displays a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, in which O2 and N3iv atoms occupy the vertex position and three atoms (O1, O2iii, O1v) and one N atom (N3vi) defines the equatorial plane [symmetry codes: (iii) 2 – x, y, 3/2 – z (iv) 1/2 + x, 1/2 + y, z (v) 2 – x, y, 3/2 – z (vi) 3/2 – x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 – z)]. The Zn2–O2 bond [2.678(5) Å] is longer than the Zn2–O1, Zn1–O4, and Zn1–O6 bonds [1.967(3), 1.942(3), and 1.919(3) Å]. The apexes bond angle O2–Zn2–N3iv is 153.28(8)°, and the bond angles around Zn2 atom vary from 52.55(9) to 116.65(6)°. The H3btc ligand in MOF-1 loses two protons to form the Hbtc2– anion and adopts one bridging coordination mode, in which the carboxylate groups adopting η1: η1:μ1 and η1:η0:μ1 (as shown in Supporting Information, Figure S1). The atz– anion is a three linker and utilizes 1,2,4-position N atoms to bridge three Zn centers, while the amino groups remain free and connected with two adjacent ones to form a 1D beautiful sinusoidal ruffling chain along the c axis (Figure S2). The amplitude of the sinusoidal chain is about 4.17 Å, whereas the period is about 15.62 Å. Each chain is connected with four neighboring ones through Hbtc2– ligands and generates a 3D framework. This arrangement leads to a rectangular open-ended, hollow single-wall nanotube with the interior cross-section dimensions of ca. 13.5 × 13.5 Å. As calculated by PLATON, MOF-1 possesses large solvent-accessible volumes with 60.02% of the unit cell volume. From the topological point of view, each Zn2 atom is connected by two atz– anions and two Hbtc2– ligands, which can be simplified as a four-connected node; each Hbtc2– ligand is simplified by a three-way tube linker linking three Zn­(II) centers. However, two adjacent Zn1 centers connected by two azt– anions can be simplified as a four-connected node. Accordingly, the whole network can be extended to a 3D 3,4,6-connected framework with the Schläfli symbol {4.62}2{4.64.8}­{46.64.85}, which is recognized for the first time (). Similarly, the Co1 and Co2 atoms in MOF-2 both present the identical ligand models with Zn1 atom as shown in Supporting Information (Figure S3 and Figure S4). Further details of the X-ray diffraction structural analyses of MOF-1 and MOF-2 are given in Table S1 and Table S3, and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S2 and Table S4. The BET surface areas were measured at 175 m2·g–1 and 179m2·g–1, and the pore volumes were 0.21 m3·g–1 and 0.11 m3·g–1, respectively, for MOF-1 and MOF-2. Using the BJH model, mesopores width of 4.8 and 4.4 nm were available in MOF-1 and MOF-2, which would provide spacious accessibility for the reactants and products to diffuse and interact with more catalytic sites.

Thermal Analysis

TGA was performed to test the thermal stability and the nature of the framework construction of MOFs. A shows the TGA curve of as-synthesized MOF-1. The preliminary 0.3% weight loss before 150 °C was speculated to the loss of absorbed water. The tardy weight loss of 11.5% within 150–360 °C corresponded to the removal of one CH3CN and two CH3OH per formula unit (cal. 11.9%). The dramatic weight loss observed within 360–430 °C indicated that the framework of MOF-1 collapsed. The TGA curve of as-synthesized MOF-2 is shown in B. The weight loss of 1.9% before 100 °C belonged to the removal of one H2O per formula unit (cal. 2.0%), and the weight loss of 15.4% within 100–200 °C corresponded to the removal of two DMF per formula unit (cal. 15.8%). Therefore, the catalysts exhibited excellent thermostability as the catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 was performed at 90 °C.

metadata.title:
Lewis Acid–Base Bifunctional Crystals with
a Three-Dimensional Framework for Selective Coupling of CO2 and Epoxides under Mild and Solvent-Free Conditions
